generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, has been a long-standing mystery. In this work, we report the synthesis of neon hydrate, which is the first example of a hydrate phase with the structure of ice II. The guest Ne atoms occupy the centers of D2O channels and have substantial freedom of movement owing to the lack of direct bonding between guest molecules and host lattices. The resolved structure where Ne dissolved in ice II is thermodynamically stable at 480 MPa and 260 K. The density distributions indicate that the vibration of Ne atoms is mainly in planes perpendicular to D2O channels, whereas their distributions along the channels are further constrained by interactions between adjacent Ne atoms. Our work provides a new route to study the structure of ice II and its stability under high pressure. It also provides a new route to study the structure of ice II-based materials under high pressure. This work is expected to be of interest to the community of materials scientists and geophysicists.

The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in the history of science. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to a certain category of sets and functions. The approach provides a framework for the foundations of quantum mechanics that is independent of any particular mathematical structure.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve food security. We quantify the magnitude of this increase in yield variability under different global warming scenarios and for the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. Our results show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most of the world. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of species matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study demonstrates the power of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for a diverse assemblage of species. This approach will be useful for understanding the role of large mammals in African savanna ecosystems and for quantifying the effects of human land use on these ecosystems.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. Our observations suggest that the missing plastic debris is transported to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and that it is rapidly fragmented into smaller particles.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the planets and the origin of life. The solar system is also the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the elements. We determined the ages of presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have cosmogenic nuclides that were produced in the interstellar medium. The grains have ages that are consistent with the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries.

The ability to produce offspring is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we examine the effect of different forms of maternal provisioning on reproductive output. We find that all forms of provisioning, including domestication and allonursing, increase reproductive output. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this orphan disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to specific stimuli. The endothelium is the first line of defense against pathogens and debris and is responsible for controlling blood pressure and blood flow. The endothelium is also the site of inflammation and is responsible for the repair of damaged blood vessels. The endothelium is a complex system that is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The goal of this paper is to understand how this network of communication channels works and how it controls the functions of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated unprecedented data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a rich set of signals of COVID-19 activity at a fine geographic resolution. The data are available in a common format and can be used to track the pandemic, augment traditional public health reporting, and empower research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at no cost and is open source. We hope that it will be useful to researchers, public health practitioners, and policymakers.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural explanation for the inversion

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The majority of the gut microbiome is made up of bacteria, but anaerobic fungi are also present in the digestive tract of herbivores. These fungi are important members of the gut microbiome, but little is known about their metabolic capabilities. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could be used as antibiotics or therapeutics. We found that anaerobic fungi produce a variety of natural products, and that these fungi are capable of producing a number of antibiotics. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important producers of natural products that could be used to treat human disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway that can affect the timing of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can mediate posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by SREBP1/SCD1-dependent lipogenesis, and can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. These findings suggest that ferroptosis-inducing agents may be used in combination with PI3K-targeting agents to treat cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease and the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with increased risk of heart failure, but the underlying mechanisms are unknown. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is dependent on the Ca2+ channel Cav1.2 and the STIM Ca2+ sensor. Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of plasma membrane ORAI channels.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but did not reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. This is partly because of the loss of older forests to fire and clearcutting on federal land. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy, and our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the plan.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our approach is a promising tool for the discovery of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train, and automatically adapts to different problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climatic event that occurred ∼12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with terrestrial Os, and that the spherules that formed at the YDB site are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Show more)

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deficiency resulted in lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and autoimmunity, which was not fatal. However, the disease was more severe in CTLA-4–deficient mice than in wild-type mice.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, revealing that both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincided with the first appearances of an arsenal of genes encoding these enzymes. Our results suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and approved antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. This work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cultural traits.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is associated with a twofold decreased risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The inner core is the densest and hottest part of the Earth. It is a key to understanding the formation of the Earth and the evolution of the core. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we found that the bcc phase of iron is more likely to nucleate than the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are well known, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are blunted in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the blunted responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of the human brain. Yet, despite its importance, the neural basis of language comprehension remains poorly understood. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks that predict brain activity during language processing also predict behavior. Our results suggest that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are fundamentally computational in nature. This view is supported by the fact that the predictive networks generalize to data from different participants and different imaging modalities. Together, these results provide a new direction for understanding the brain basis of language. They also have implications for understanding the evolution of language and for developing artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is not clear whether this success is due to the inherent properties of DL or to the fact that DL algorithms are more stable than other algorithms. We address this question by studying the relationship between stability and approximation properties of problems. We prove that there are problems for which there exist stable neural networks with great approximation qualities, but there does not exist any algorithm that can compute such a network. This result implies a classification theory of stability and approximation properties. We introduce a new algorithm, called fast iterative restarted networks, which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of the public to comply with the necessary restrictions. One of the most prominent arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Here, we discuss the critical design flaws of this experiment and show that they are responsible for the widely cited conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth.

Leprosy is a disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. In contrast, the pathogen associated with a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, M. lepromatosis, is uncultured and has a near-complete genome sequence. We compared the genomes of these two organisms and found that they are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation.

The dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of quantum information theory and statistical mechanics. It is also of great practical relevance, as it is the basis for the development of quantum error correction codes and for the implementation of quantum algorithms. However, the dynamics of entanglement is a very difficult problem, as it is nonperturbative and nonlocal. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the dynamics of entanglement in a wide class of quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. To control the pandemic, a large-scale vaccination program is needed. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature, which is expected to facilitate large-scale manufacturing. In addition, the vaccine candidate is highly attenuated in vivo, resulting in milder lung pathology and reduced weight loss compared to wild-type virus. The vaccine candidate is also highly protective in hamsters, suggesting that it could be used in a mass vaccination program.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, is often described as the Black Death. However, the role of human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, in the spread of plague is still debated. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of plague, as it would imply that the use of rat control measures was not the only factor that led to the decline of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of brain power. However, to get a less biased picture of the evolutionary paths leading to high cognitive power, we need to compare brains not by mass but by numbers of neurons. This study reconstructs the evolution of brains across amniotes by directly analyzing neuron numbers. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncoprotein. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator that promotes a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor by promoting a metabolic switch that favors the use of fatty acids for energy production. This may help explain the inverse correlation between TRAP1 expression and tumor grade in several cancers.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the barbed end of the filament and severing it. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin is able to sever actin filaments in a mechanical-torque-dependent manner. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanism is a general principle that is used by many proteins to sever filaments in a mechanical-torque-dependent manner. This is important because many biological processes, such as cell migration, are regulated by the mechanical state of the actin cytoskeleton.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is widely used in the United States. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake are not well understood. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite and may promote feeding behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic growth happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher proportion of males than females immigrating from Africa. Finally, we show that the genetic structure is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a nonuniform way. We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of “emotional contagion” that occurs without direct interaction between individuals. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact with them in person. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our findings have implications for the design of social networks, as well as for the study of the spread of emotions in society.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of mRNA modifications can have profound effects on mRNA stability, translation, and protein function. Here, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have subtle effects on the decoding of mRNA sequences and the rate of protein synthesis. These findings highlight the importance of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and predictors, and they are maintained over time.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most studied topics in biology. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that rhinovirus replicates preferentially at cool temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

The type IV pili of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are used for a variety of functions, including twitching motility, biofilm formation, and sensing surfaces. Here we show that type IV pili can also be used as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the pili. This mechanosensitive pili-based sensor is used to regulate the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. This is the first example of a bacterial mechanosensitive sensor that is not based on the activity of the cell wall.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. In this study, we describe the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer and that the virus is likely to persist in the wild animal population. This study has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and for the development of a “One Health” approach to monitor and mitigate the spread of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the history of large dams, the current situation, and the challenges of moving toward sustainable hydropower. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

The presence of amyloid plaques is often considered the primary driver of the chronic neuroinflammation that is characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors that trigger the microglial response. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels, and that these molecules correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization. Importantly, we identify an inflammatory profile unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, since neighboring glial cells did not express similar molecules. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. These findings have important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. The earliest archaeological evidence for the domestication of chickens comes from the Neolithic sites of Çatalhöyük and Catal Huyuk in southern Mesopotamia. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. The results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the maltose binding protein, which is known to fold in two steps. We find that the protein collapses rapidly into a polyglobular state, which then collapses further to a distinct intermediate. The intermediate is composed of segments that are distant in the sequence but adjacent in the native protein. The intermediate folds to the native state in a longer step. These results suggest that the intermediate is a native-like structure. They also suggest that the folding of a large protein may involve distinct steps. This is a major advance in our understanding of protein folding. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme ApaH is inactivated by Np4, which enables accumulation of the caps to high levels. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH is the predominant decapping enzyme, and that it prefers to remove the Np4 cap over the triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine deprivation is a mechanism that contributes to the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a potential therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a quantitative basis for the study of the impact of humans on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and, after a transient, reaches a state of criticality in which the system evolves on its own without being externally controlled. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a new route to the development of diamond-based devices. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices and for the understanding of the fundamental properties of diamond.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of animals is less clear. Here, we show that the evolution of the immune system in animals is linked to the evolution of plant-associated microorganisms. We also show that the immune system of animals evolved in response to plant-associated microorganisms.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome after mating and that they support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is essential for blood clotting. It binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to form a complex that delivers clotting factors to the site of injury. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-dependent switching of VWF is a general mechanism for activating receptors. It may be important for many other proteins that bind to cell surfaces.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. In recent years, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has also gained momentum, but the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the analysis of the impact of viruses on human health. We present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. We also provide a resource for the analysis of virus–disease associations, which is the largest of its kind as well. Together, these resources will enable the study of the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. The HSRL is expected to provide a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. The K+ channel BK is a major regulator of vascular tone and plays a key role in cardiac arrhythmia. The BK channel normally shows no C-type inactivation, and its activation and deactivation are fast. We found that the BK channel has two distinct gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation.

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the human red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane. We show that this interaction reduces the energy barrier to invasion by reducing the bending modulus of the RBC membrane. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a new route to control the properties of diamond, which is important for its applications. This work will also help to understand the relationship between the properties of diamond and its strain.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of influenza virus infection and host defense, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine and therapy. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of syntactic structure follows a tree-like pattern, but that the tree is built up one branch at a time. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to combine words into phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in development, tissue homeostasis, and cancer. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled and the downstream component Dishevelled. In this study, we show that the two components of the Axin scaffold, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific regulation of the pathway, which is important for the proper functioning of the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical or optogenetic stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), as well as dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc). We also show that LH stimulation-induced eating is dependent on dopamine neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the LH. Finally, we show that lesions of dopamine neurons in the peri-LH region or in the VTA block LH stimulation-induced eating. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability of bacteria to fix atmospheric nitrogen is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle. This process is of particular interest in agriculture, where it is estimated that 15% of the world’s crop production is nitrogen deficient. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to cereal crops, without the need for synthetic nitrogen fertilizers. Here, we describe the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to monitor and deter deforestation, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads and detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C of warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing anthropogenic aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the availability of recombinant protein vaccines is well established. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in a recombinant protein vaccine. The variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This variant can be expressed in large quantities in microbial systems, and the vaccine can be produced at low cost. This variant can be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine, which can be produced at even lower cost. This work provides a potential solution to the global vaccine shortage.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in the development of many tissues and is implicated in a variety of human cancers. In the zebrafish, the DrALKs are involved in the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived pigment cells. Here, we show that the DrALKs are able to activate the DrLtk and the human ALK/LTK family members. We further show that loss of DrALKs results in the loss of iridophores, whereas loss of DrLtk leads to the formation of ectopic iridophores. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of the DrALKs in neural crest development and suggest that the DrALKs are potential therapeutic targets in zebrafish and human neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution and spread are poorly understood. Here, we present the genomes of 17 plague strains from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which spans over 3,000 y. Our results reveal a single lineage of plague that persisted over millennia without significant diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM predicted evaluations of Trump, across studies, social and prejudiced attitudes predicted evaluations of his democratic challengers: Clinton in 2016 and Biden in 2020. We replicate the findings of Studies 1 through 6 using a nationally representative sample of the United States (Study 7) 50 days prior to the 2020 presidential election. The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has released a large amount of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The results show that the management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and used this to rank the spillover potential of 887 viruses from animals. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of the spillover potential of 887 viruses provides a resource for prioritizing research and public health interventions. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that this resource will be used to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animal pollinators for the transfer of pollen between plants. The color of nectar is an important cue for pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the evolution of color in nectar are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of color in nectar and the mechanisms that underlie the evolution of this important trait for plant reproduction. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 450 and 750 AD. Our results indicate that women had a much more complex genetic history than men, with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period and suggest that complex demographic processes may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating the spread of emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and leptospirosis. Our findings highlight the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can help to deploy rapid public health response to emerging threats. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves two DNA polymerases, pol δ and pol ε, and the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The mechanism of this process is not well understood, in part because of the lack of kinetic assays that can measure the stability of the pol δ–PCNA complex. We developed a unique assay that allows us to measure the stability of the pol δ–PCNA complex in human cells. Our results indicate that the pol δ–PCNA complex is not stable and dissociates rapidly. This is important for understanding the mechanism of DNA synthesis on the lagging strand of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, it is possible to create RNA molecules that store genetic information, but it has not been possible to create an RNA polymerase that can replicate RNA. Here, we describe the creation of an RNA polymerase that can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs. This work represents a significant step toward the creation of a functional RNA-based cell. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus is a leading cause of invasive fungal disease, and the development of antifungal resistance is a major concern. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to metal ions is critical for their survival, and the identification of fungal natural products that bind and impact metal homeostasis is a promising area of research. Here we describe the identification of a fungal natural product that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in metal homeostasis and the development of antifungal resistance. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary deposit is also significant because it is a rare sedimentary mineral on Earth. The sedimentary deposit at Marias Pass, Gale crater, is a catchment deposit of a “Lake Gale” that formed in a silicic volcanic environment.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We analyze the geographic distribution of frost events and the resistance strategies of trees to infer the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the development of colitis by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. In addition, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of a subset of Th17 cells that retain an IL-17A+ phenotype. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the only cells in the human body that cannot be replaced. We have developed a method to convert human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease and screen for drugs that can alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will also enable rapid production of motor neuron disease models for preclinical testing of potential therapies. This will be a major advance in ALS research. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work also provides a model for how pathogens can use the host immune system to manipulate the microbiota to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The discovery of a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, the clade Pygostylia, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian bauplan. This study describes a new species of early bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. In this paper, we show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is associated with the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main product of the catabolism of hemoglobin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the growth of breast cancer cells in the hypoxic microenvironment is important for the development of new therapies. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is regulated by HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is dependent on ALKBH5. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. Understanding the cause of the extinction and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depends on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unknown. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the cellular receptor, and the human antibody, MTRX-E, which neutralizes infection. The structure of the complex reveals a key mechanism for neutralization and provides a framework for the development of future therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
