COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.18 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This model can be used to predict the behavior of compounds under pressure, and to predict the behavior of new compounds under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the effects of this on the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the impact of climate change on fire activity, and that this can offset some of the warming caused by CO2 emissions. This suggests that fire suppression and ignitions can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. However, with more extreme fires, there is a risk of more damage to ecosystems and human infrastructure.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts, and that the glycan catabolism is required for the acidification of the luminescent crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. This study provides a new example of how animals can regulate the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly used to understand the world around us. However, the complexity of text data makes it difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of text data. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents. Here, we show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague outbreaks. We find that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a rapidly spreading disease affecting a large number of species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is caused by a virus that is transmitted by the crown-of-thorns starfish (Acanthaster planci). Here, we show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the SSWD.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and approved antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. This work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing a wealth of information on crop status and condition. However, the information is not easily accessible, and is often not used to improve crop management decisions. We show that the information is rich and can be used to monitor crop status and predict yields earlier and more accurately than official forecasts. Our work provides a framework for using crop expert information to monitor crop status and predict yields, and can be used to improve the accuracy of crop management decisions.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance for predicting future changes in the carbon cycle. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is characterized by the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a new lifestyle, which is characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first artificial quasicrystals were synthesized in the laboratory in the 1980s. In this paper, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of artificial quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, which was created by the detonation of a nuclear bomb, provides a unique link between the laboratory and the real world.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a promising approach to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (Show more)

The news media are a critical source of information for the public, and the content of the news is a key determinant of the public’s information intake. This work reports on a large-scale, cross-national experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive information. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that the tendency for news to be predominantly negative is widespread. They also show that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a variety of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and a congenital myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. However, the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous and that it is dependent on active release of aggregates from the cell of origin. These findings provide a model for the propagation of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that the use of Drosophila as a model system for studying the spread of protein aggregates may be fruitful. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is thought to protect them from pathogen invasion. However, the immunosuppressive mechanism of bats is poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized a unique immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in the bat, Myotis pilosus, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is the rate-limiting enzyme in the conversion of serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, targeting one-carbon metabolism may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in ALS is a key feature that distinguishes this disease from other neurodegenerative disorders. However, the reasons for the presence of these proteins in inclusions are not clear. Here, we show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is due to a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the photonic crystal system is a promising platform for a wide range of applications in quantum optics and atom optics. The system is also a promising platform for studying the physics of many-body systems, including the physics of topological phases and the physics of topological insulators. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a new genus and species, provides a link between the earliest known aquatic angiosperms and the first appearance of the Ceratophyllum clade. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is the earliest known angiosperm with a flower with a perianth.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These findings emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is used to project future sea level rise. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the rate of acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration of global warming.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme catalysis is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts, and that the glycan catabolism is required for the acidification of the luminescent crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. This study provides a new example of how animals can control the composition of their microbial communities by regulating the provision of specific nutrients. This is a common strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities.

The suspension rate in US schools is the highest in the developed world. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which can reduce suspension rates. The study also shows that this mindset can be sustained over time, and that it can improve students’ respect for teachers and their motivation to behave well in class. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) proteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. In the United Kingdom, the food system is responsible for 22% of greenhouse gas emissions, and this share is likely to increase as the population grows and diets change. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.5%. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our findings suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a simple and effective way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and land use change.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic environment that is constantly being remodeled by the cell to engage the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostics and therapeutics. The development of a vaccine and therapeutics for COVID-19 has been hampered by the lack of knowledge about the molecular basis of the disease. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide a foundation for the development of therapeutics that target this important viral protein. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. In conclusion,

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that we find in a dataset, given that we have chosen which associations to look for. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help to make the problem more accessible to a broad audience.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). ETV2 is essential for the development of ETVECs, and ETV2 is sufficient to induce the expression of endothelial development factors in fibroblasts. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. (Show more)

The discovery of “orphan” RTKs has led to the identification of their physiological ligands. In this study, we demonstrate that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands for a pair of orphan RTKs, a situation that is unique among vertebrates. We show that these ligands are essential for iridophore patterning in the eye and in the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a unique model system to study the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands. (Show more)

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemic. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and takes place in infected cells. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions.

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions are not well understood. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical mechanism in the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the infection of cells in the brain is likely a key step in the pathogenesis of ZIKV. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in the brain of a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual animals, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results provide a framework for understanding the disease process and for assessing the potential impact of a treatment. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. While the symptoms of bleaching have been extensively characterized, the underlying causes remain poorly understood. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide insights into the metabolic interactions between coral and symbiont and may help to explain the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in general. This may ultimately help to uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex barrier that protects the host from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The development of resistance to chemotherapy is a major obstacle to the treatment of breast cancer. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the capacity of breast cancer cells to form breast cancer patient-derived xenografts and to metastasize. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that the onset of rapid climate change occurred as early as ∼18.0 ka, whereas others argue that the onset occurred only after ∼17.7 ka. Here, we show that the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series that occurred at the same time as a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a decrease in stratospheric ozone.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries that can be used to assess the importance of inland fisheries for food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are responsible for the high capacity and low operating potential. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work also provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a critical feature of the adult nervous system. In the past decade, we have made significant progress in understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate. However, the mechanisms that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system are less well understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling cascade. We also identify a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon growth in the same neuron type. These findings provide a unique platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. They also suggest that the mechanisms that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the nervous system are more similar than previously thought.

The process of DNA recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in all organisms. In eukaryotes, the process is highly variable, with some regions of the genome undergoing many crossovers, whereas others are virtually devoid of them. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination events in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination initiation has been conserved in eukaryotes for over a billion years.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, which are active in the absence of task performance. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been controversial. Here, we used metabolic PET to validate the RSN hypothesis in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), but that this RSN was subordinated in Parkinson’s disease (PD). In addition, we found that the DMN was reduced in PD, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we found that the DMN was reduced in Alzheimer’s disease, and that this abnormality was already present at diagnosis. These results provide a direct link between the metabolic organization of the brain and the function of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of mRNA. However, there are many other modifications that have been found on mRNA, including the recently described 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA in bacteria. Here we show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We also show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and that it is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. (Show more)

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study that demonstrated the importance of glycemic control in the prevention of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The long-term follow-up of the DCCT participants, the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, has shown that glycemic control during the DCCT has a long-term effect on the progression of microvascular complications. We found that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the EDIC Study, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. (Show more)

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective treatment options. We show that the tumor suppressor fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier and behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of a distinctive aroma. However, the biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these important flavor compounds. It also opens the door to the development of new strategies for improving the flavor of tomato and other fruit crops. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the local map of space, including the direction of the animal’s head relative to the environment, the boundaries of rooms, and the orientation of objects. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that the neurons encoding the animal’s head direction are strongly coupled, but not connected, to the neurons encoding the boundaries of rooms. These findings provide a new perspective on the organization of the MEC. (Show more)

Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study demonstrates that the flowering signal FT is required for both host and parasite flowering. This is unique in the plant kingdom, where most parasites are thought to be nonflowering. The study also illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized form of nigral innervation of the striatum. We show that striatonigral fibers form highly unusual arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent cell bodies. These clusters of cell bodies, in turn, project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know when we’re feeling connected to someone, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SA) cells, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. The SA cells are also responsible for maintaining heart rate in the face of changes in blood pressure and other hemodynamic signals. Here, we report that the activity of the SA cells is regulated by a mechanism that links the content of calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum with the electrical activity of the plasma membrane. This mechanism is mediated by stromal interaction molecule 1, a regulator of store-operated calcium entry. Our findings have important implications for understanding the mechanisms that regulate the pacemaking function of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivory. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to support this process, including the maintenance of elevated neural activity. Here we propose a different approach to memory in the nervous system. Instead of relying on sustained activity, we show that information can be stored by changes in the excitability of individual neurons. This mechanism is based on the idea that the firing rate of a neuron is a measure of its activity. By changing the firing rate, we can change the amount of information that a neuron can encode. This work provides a new perspective on the neural basis of language processing. It may also have implications for understanding the development of language and the evolution of human intelligence.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall in plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, but that their nutrient loads are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to these watersheds.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We also find that the dynamics of the network are sensitive to the details of the environment, and that the system can exhibit a variety of behaviors depending on the strength of the forcing. These results suggest that the dynamics of complex systems can be strongly influenced by the details of the environment in which they operate.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which in turn changes the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are critical for the development of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs and may help to explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same parameters that are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition may be critical for the development of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may help to explain the difficulty in predicting which patients will develop paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. Finally, our findings may help to explain the differences in EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs and other autoimmune encephalitis. This may help to explain the difficulty in predicting which patients will develop paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. Finally, our findings may help to explain the differences in EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs and other autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is critical to understanding the Earth system and its response to external forcing. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. The event is also associated with a significant perturbation of the carbon cycle, including a large injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 9.8 to 6.6% y−1, but that most of the remaining forest was degraded. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single gene, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex is determined by multiple genes, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of secondary sexual characteristics. In contrast to single-locus sex determination, which broadly results in sexual dimorphism, multiple alleles can induce higher-order sexual polymorphism. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and RPE cells, respectively. The RPE is also challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by ROS and photodegraded into damaging species. We show that the intracellular levels of iron (Fe) impact the retina. Specifically, we show that Fe promotes the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Predators are the key to understanding the structure and functioning of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as predators are constrained by the need to evolve morphological and functional adaptations throughout the body. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a case of morphological modularity. We show that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology and mode of evolution of the tentacles, and that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology and mode of evolution of the tentacles, and to the evolution of the prey types that they capture.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the hominin lineage leading to humans and Neandertals is relatively poor between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of the Acheulian technology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This is an important step in understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human hand morphology. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is the rate-limiting enzyme in the conversion of serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, targeting one-carbon metabolism may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also provides a method for using observational data to show that natural landscapes can have a causal impact on people’s diets. This is a significant advance in the field of nutrition geography.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
